mission not really accomplished there, I

that's nuts. That's
I mean, as far as I'm concerned, I do

owners of this car, the 992.1 Turbo S, I

so I think once it gets in front of more
people's faces, I think then we'll see
an uptick in the amount of people that
actually want to put their money behind
this potentially. But I mean,
>> it is compromised in very specific ways
that would make it hard to live with
>> in certain regions. in certain regions
like here. And so there's only going to
be so many people in California that
want to spend $40,000 on this versus a
Tesla or, you know, an EV6 or or
something along those lines.
>> Yeah. Norm equivalently priced efficient
standard EV.
>> It's interesting. I think my my theory
is that it it's different and that's
what's getting all the attention. It's
maybe too different to get people to
commit to buying it.
>> But it is interesting enough that it
could potentially push the industry a
little bit, which is exciting.
>> Yeah. I think if you're just looking for
practicality and to do something
different and not spend a a ton of money
on an EV, because a lot of these EVs are
very expensive and not giving you a
whole lot for that money as far as
usability. Yeah.
>> I think that's where,
you know, this car might have a pocket
to to sit in. All right. Well, give it a
year. See where we're at. Yeah. Check
back in.
>> Yeah.
>> Thanks for watching. Catch you in the

title: The Glow Up is Crazy
description:
The new Kia EV6 has a lot going for it!

Shot on iPhone 17 Pro Max
Rode Wireless Micro: https://geni.us/FBnQh
transcript:
All right, you want to talk about
glow-ups for new products that nobody's
really talking about for some reason. I
would like to nominate Kia with this new
EV6. This is nice. They've done a lot of
good stuff here. First new glowup is the
new front end. Okay, so these new
headlights, they've grown on me, but I
think they look nice. This whole front
end has been redesigned. But the second
glow up is the battery. So the first gen
had a 77 kWh battery. This has grown to
now an 84 kWh. So, the GT line, which is
the one I have here, will do well over
300 mi, which is nice. But then third
glow up is this is an NACS port now. So,
you can plug into Tesla superchargers
with no adapter needed and charge in a
ton of places. You still get this light
here, which indicates how full you are,
and it's still a motorized charging
door. Nice. But then the fourth glow up
is on the inside, which is wireless
CarPlay and Android Auto. I don't know
why it took him so long, but it's
welcome. But then the fifth glow-up is
this updated interior styling. It feels
a lot more premium and visually
interesting on the inside now. This new
dual tone steering wheel is cool. And
this new wireless charging pad on this
floating armrest is ideal. So yeah,
shout out to the new EV6. If it wasn't
already on your radar with all this glow
up, now it probably should

title: The Best Alternatives to Every Tesla
description:
My alternative EVs for Tesla Model 3, Model Y, Model S, Model X and Cybertruck.

Rode Wireless Micro: https://geni.us/FBnQh

So, okay, being someone that reviews a
lot of cars, one of the most common

are the best non-Tesla electric cars
that I could buy?" And I always like
making videos about like answering the
most frequently asked questions, but if
you'd asked me to make this video like
10 years ago, it would have been a
really short video. I would have said,
"Nah, good luck. The Tesla is the EV you
should buy."
But now it's 2025 and Tesla still makes
a great product, but with them opening
up the supercharging network and lots of
other competition getting way more
popular and way better, now there are
way more alternatives that are actually
worthy of considering. So, in the
fiveish categories that Tesla makes a
vehicle, I'm going to actually give you
my top five, no, top three alternatives
to Model 3, Model Y, Model S, and Model
X. and Cybertruck. And this is the video
that I'm gonna send to people who ask me
that question. Also, me standing in
front of this new facelifted EV6 and it
not making any of my lists. The irony is
not lost on me, but this is a good
runner up. Anyway, let's get into it.
Okay, let's start with uh Tesla's most
popular vehicle, their best deal,
Tesla Model 3. So, Model 3 buyers are
looking for, you know, a pretty
reasonable compactish four-door sedan
they can take friends around in. good
range, efficient, nothing too fancy. So,
my top pick, and I've reviewed this car,
actually, actually, I've reviewed every
single car that I'm about to talk about
in this video on this channel, so you
can go back and watch them, but I'll say
my top pick for this is the Hyundai
Ionic 6. The six is uh basically the
same range as a Model 3. It's about 320
mi. Uh the new one in 2026 is going to
have an NACS port, so you can plug in
without an adapter into a bunch of Tesla
superchargers. The design,
you know, some people might like it,
some people might not. It looks like
kind of a baby Porsche from certain
angles, but it's also a little unique.
Definitely have to like the look of it
to spend the money on it. But it has
CarPlay andor Android Auto if you want
that, too. Unlike a Model 3, of course.
Cheap used ones, like you can get a good
clean title used one for like 20 grand
now. So, that's a good deal, a good
range, a good reliable EV, and as long
as you don't mind the looks, that's my
top pick. Now, to round out my top
three, I have two cars that I think are
a just a little bit more interesting
than the Model 3. Something that I hear
also a lot from people about why they
don't want a Tesla is because there's so

has. So, I'm going with Polestar 2. This
is not a very common one. It's not even

exterior design of Polestars a lot. Uh,

will also say Volvo EX30. I really like
the Volvo EX30. I think it's way more

Auto, and you can get one in the range
of 40 grand uh used. They're they're
pretty new still, but it is a smaller
EV, more compact back seat, a little bit
more environmentally friendly materials
on the inside, but just a little bit
more interesting than a Model 3. So,
that's my top three Model 3
alternatives. Now, next up, Tesla has
the Model Y, which is literally I think
it might still be the most popular
vehicle on the planet. So, obviously,
there's a lot of them and it is popular
for good reason. It's really good. It's
a really good deal and uh wouldn't shock

alternative to one, my top pick is going
to be the BMW iX. So, we're thinking
Model Y, two rows, obviously, but a

off the ground. BMW EX is very similar

mile range, but if you don't want to pay

sportier feeling interior. Uh, it's not

looks pretty good, too. I think the
suspension is a little bit better. And
yeah, it's going to have a lot of the
same upsides in terms of space and a
simple, modern interior. plus CarPlay
and Android Auto. So, you can find used
EX's around the 40 grand mark for a
clean title one. Now, my second on this
list is is actually one of my favorites
I reviewed a long time ago when there
were almost none of them on the road,
and I called them underrated. Cadillac
L. So, the Lyric is what you get if you
want a more premium interior version of
the Model Y. The Model Y is super clean,
obviously, but the Cadillac interior
does it much nicer. Uh, it has better
sound dampening. It has better uh seats,
I think, and it also rides a bit better.
It's a bit softer. So, if you want that
softer ride, Cadillac L is pretty sweet.
It has Super Cruise standard. So, if you
want that hands off the wheel driving
experience, you got that. And then NACS
via an adapter. I don't think they have

can get down into the 35ish range for a

And then rounding out my top three,

basics, but it's also just it's
definitely more interesting than the
most popular vehicle on planet Earth.
Um, it has a lot of interesting features

little crystal interior elements and
obviously a very different looking
interior. It also has CarPlay and
Android Auto. That's going to be a theme
here for a lot of the alternatives to
Teslas which don't have that. But it
also is just a good performer. The maxed
out performance version of the GV60 is a
better performer than the Model Y
performance if you're interested in
that. But if you want a base one or if
you're just trying to get to a lower
price, you can get all the way down to
30 grand for a used GV60. So, with
features like summoning it out of a

just did interesting things with the

it rounds out my top three Model Y
alternatives. So, that's Model 3 and
Model Y. But, what if you're in the

in the car are great. It drives super
well. It also has CarPlay and Android

like I got to double check, but I think

then rounding out my top three, I would
say look at the BMW i5
M60 trim. So again, this is going to be

and it's a lot of the basics are the

a good fundamental EV are still there.
Good range and all that. But if you just
want something a little more interesting
than all the Model S's you see around
the BMW i5.
The i7 is huge. You could still go i7.
The i3 is a little smaller. We'll get
there, but I think i5 is a nice sweet

the Lucid Gravity feels very much aimed

All these have flaws. There's been a lot

CarPlay support yet with the Lucid
Gravity, but in general, as far as a

great NVH, super quiet, ton of space on
the inside, a ton of storage, great
premium materials. like it's just aimed
at being the ultimate alternative to the
Model X. So, yeah, it succeeded. Now, a
very close second and third on my list
are vehicles I really like. Second, I
think you guys should check Rivian R1S.
I mean, that's a pretty clear one. Three

like the adventure capability side. So,
they have a ton of specs, a ton of SKs

So, that's pretty good. But then you

EX90.
This one was a surprise to me. I hadn't

Uh, now it does have that that little

definitely a premiumba
and adventure oriented electric truck

Shout out to the Rivian R1T. It even has

onetoone as far as pure capabilities

the different capabilities of the thing.
And the Chevy Silverado EV is a strong

title: Mercedes G-Wagen EV - Terrible Specs But That's Not the Point
description:
The Mercedes G580 with EQ Technology does a 360 with the G-Wagen formula.

Shot on iPhone 17 Pro Max
Rode Wireless Micro: https://geni.us/FBnQh
transcript:
[Music]
So, in the world of electric cars, there
are groundup EVs, and then there's
recycling the old design, but making it
electric. And I usually prefer the
groundup EV. It's more efficient. You
get more space. It just feels like a
more well-considered product. But
sometimes, sometimes you got to keep the
old design. And this is one of those
examples. This is definitely the old
design, but electric mostly. So, this is
the electric G Wagon, or more
specifically, one of the G Wagons, the
one that happens to be electric. This is
the G580 with EQ technology, and it's
positioned basically as the middle tier
option. It's right above the inline
six-powered G550 and the V8 powered AMG
G63. So, it's not replacing the gas
models. It's just one of the G Wagons
has an electric powertrain. And to me,
it makes a lot of sense. So, you want to
preserve this iconic G Wagon thing, but
kind of prepare it for the future a
little bit. Now, the specs of this one,
h, they're not great. Okay, they're not
great. It is a quad motor vehicle with
all-wheel drive, and it makes about 579
horsepower and 859 lb-ft of torque, but
it also weighs almost 7,000 lb. So, it
deserves 60 and 4.1 seconds. And it has
a 116 kWh battery pack. But because it's
still shaped like a G Wagon, which
people like, it does not have great
aerodynamics. That's about as
aerodynamic as a tombstone. So, you're
going to get like 240 mi of range if
you're chilling. Uh, and of course, it's
worse in the winter. So, it's not the
most efficient. It's not the best
numbers, but if you want the G Wagon
experience, but electric, that's what
this is delivering. So, aesthetically on
the outside, you know, this looks very
familiar. It does do a couple special
things like this grill at the front
doesn't have to be as massive of a
radiator. You can still see a radiator
in there, but this uh lights up as an
LED at night, which is cool. But then
you get around the side and there's no
mistaking this for anything else. It's
clearly a G Wagon. Super boxy. You've
got that flat front, the lights at the
corners, this line right through the
middle of the entire vehicle, 20-in
wheels that it's sitting on, and the
charge port, the electric one's back
right corner, which I thought was
interesting. It's not the most common

right for your charge port. And then you

there's that obviously iconic spare spot

There's no sub trunk or anything, but
that's plenty of space by my standards.
And of course, a little luxury touches
everywhere with the the crosshatched
leather. And uh I want to make sure the
mic picks this up. So this is what it
sounds like to close the door.
That's nice. This is what it sounds like
to lock the door.
That's so nice. I really hope the mic
picks that up because that is a pretty
pretty classic G Wagon experience. Just
the sound of opening and closing the
doors. And this all continues once you
get inside this thing. Once you pass the
MercedesBenz branded corner lights and
the EQ badge to know it's the electric
one and even the the letter G on the
handles. That's when you pop in and get
into the G Wagon's driver's seat and you
understand why people spend so much for
these things because it's a it's a
Mercedes and the luxuries is everywhere.
It does have a push button start. I
don't love that in every AV, but I guess
they keep that just to keep people
familiar. And yeah, there's a lot going
on here. I'm actually glad they didn't
go all screens or do something crazy
like I just saw with the new Porsche
Cayenne going electric. They they very
much kept this in line with the rest of
the G Wagon lineup. Meaning you still
have Mercedes software with all of their
Windows 7 looking, you know, holographic
lightsaber tachometer and all that, but
it's surrounded by more physical luxury.
Nice materials, a nice grab handle, the
vents with little LED lights in them
like all the Mercedes stuff you're used
to seeing. And then of course some real
vents down here or real buttons down
here.
nice hazard sound. Uh, and also for
changing temperature and fan speed, but
a single wireless charger as well. You
get two USB type-C ports. There is
wireless Android Auto and CarPlay.
There's the two cup holders, the swipe
pad, which is always here, and then the
dynamic button to switch between your
drive modes. And then a little bit of
storage in the middle. But I think maybe
the part of the interior that symbolizes
the GWAC luxury the most is the seats.
these huge hefty seats which are
obviously leather and stitched really
nicely but are heated are ventilated.
They'll massage you and they actually
have these adjustable like the headrest
here will like cradle your head in place
if you want it to. And these bolsters by
default uh move quite a bit. They're
active. So, if I turn, they kind of hug

And they move quite a bit. And I think
they respond to geforce, if I'm
understanding them correctly, because
they can get accidentally triggered by

you. If I turn right and I move to the

visibility is great. Uh, all the windows

because this uh this stuff is up here,

legally they have to render certain

Um, and these are actually not quite

if the user has an iPhone? That's a
really weird question. I feel like, and
we've seen this from Tesla and from
Rivian so far, there are car companies
who are are pretty sure they don't want
to do that and they don't support

list of companies who are going to
support CarPlay Ultra. If you own an
Aston Martin already, I think you can
get your car to a service center and

extra integration in a sort of an Apple

Because to me, it's just a little bit

title: The Escalade IQ *actually* has 500 Miles of Range!

gen quad motor Rivian R1T? Some people
might say it's the paint color. I don't
think so. A lot of people would say the
lights. This front light bar, if you
remember, the second gen is actually a
battery percentage indicator when it's
charging. 60, 70, 80, all the way to
100%. That's pretty cool, but it's not
that. For some people, it's the wheel
and tire package. This is the first time
they've done staggered wheels and tires.
new tire. Uh sticky Pilot Sport 5S on
this thing, but it's not that. Uh for
some people it's the new color. So blue
is the accent color. This teal blue on
the Rivian logo and on the new brakes.
Actually, it's the same brakes, just
painted blue. Uh that's for just the
quad. So if you see that or if you see
that Yeti logo, then the thing you're
driving behind has 1,000 horsepower.
But it's not that for me, or at least
for people in the US, I guess, I think
the most interesting thing about this
truck is the fact that it's the first
non-Tesla EV that I have tested with the
Tesla charge port built in. No adapter
needed, NACS. That's going to seem very
normal to people in Europe, but I've
been waiting for this for a long time.
So, apparently all the second generation
Rivians are now going to start shipping
with that. I've charged with it, plugged
it in, no problem.
Finally.

title: My Next Daily Driver? - 911 GTS T-Hybrid
description:
The Porsche 911 992.2 GTS is a Hybrid! But barely...

Shot on iPhone 16 Pro Max
Rode Wireless Micro: https://geni.us/FBnQh
transcript:
So, I was talking to someone the other
day about if the electric car is
actually the future of cars guaranteed.
And I don't know if that's actually
necessarily definitely true. But what I
do know to be true is the electric motor
specifically.
Well, that's coming. It's actually
basically everywhere. So much everywhere
that even the Porsche 911 can't resist.
This is the newest 992.2 generation
Carrera 4 GTS. And you can see that
badge down here at the bottom. It says T
hybrid because there is an electric
motor in the turbo specifically. Now, I
was very, very interested in testing
this new generation specifically because
Porsche does not take changes to the 911
lightly. Anything that they do will be
scrutinized and analyzed to the nth
degree because it's an iconic car and
making the first hybrid version of it is
a huge deal. So, they must have a really
good reason to. And turns out, I agree,
really good reason. It's not the typical
hybrid, though. Some people would argue
you don't even really need to call it a
hybrid just because there are electric
motors and a bit of a new battery. We'll
get to that, though. The basics, though,
are this is still a 911. Carrera 4 GTS
is a all-wheel drive GTS, and it's
really expensive. Priced as tested, just
under $200,000
for a 3.6 6 L re-engineered flat 6 with
that electric motor we talked about, a
1.9 kWh battery. Now, like I said,
Porsche does not make a whole ton of
changes to the 911 without really good
reasons. So, from the outside, it's
going to mostly look like the same car
as last year and the year before and the
generation before. There are very few
subtle changes that they actually decide
to make. For example, the easiest way to
know you're driving next to a 992.2 is
these new shark fin gills in the front
here. I actually didn't like the way
these look at first. In pictures, they
don't look nearly as good. But something
about like a lot of this matte plastic
at the bottom versus the glossy. And
these are also active, so they open up
more in sport plus mode and when the
brakes need cooling and you need more
air flow and then they'll close like
this in regular driving. I kind of grown
to like it. It looks really good. This
is the whole front diffuser. Not bad. On
the side, obviously, not a whole lot
different other than the T hybrid badge
that I keep pointing out on both sides.
Still some good thick tires and 21in and
20in wheels. And then this is the back.
This one I I don't like that they have
this uh this fake exhaust tip. See how
it's disconnected from the actual
exhaust. I mean, you wouldn't know that
unless you walk right up to the car, but
I feel like on a $200,000 Porsche, like
you could connect those, I guess. Aside
from that though, very normal looking
back of a 992 generation car. That is
also active arrow. That spoiler goes up
and down. Okay, it's still a 911. So,
all right then. T- hybrid. What does
that mean? This is the first hybrid 911,
which is a huge deal. What does that
actually mean for this car? What is
included? Well, there's the 1.9 kWh
battery and there's the two electric
motors that I talked about. In total, it
only adds maybe 50 kg to the entire
weight of the car. So, not that much.
Virtually undetectable while driving.
And it doesn't even really change the
packaging. It is a reworked engine to
get the electric parts in there. Uh, but
the front trunk, for example, is still
the exact same size. So, in a 911 where
you want that practicality, the battery
is actually right back here. If I take
this plastic cover off, should I take it
off? All right, I'll take it off. I'll
show you where the battery is. Take this
whole thing off. There's the 1.9 kow
battery. So, the flirt trunk that lives
up here is still the same size, and it's
great. In fact, the packaging is so
good, I think if you just put a regular
person in this car and sat them down and
told them to drive it, they would not be
able to tell that it's a hybrid. It's
not a plug-in hybrid and at no point do
the electric motors ever drive the car.
There is no electric mode. But what
they've done with this is very clever.
So without doing a whole history lesson,
basically turbos are very common, are
very popular in these quick cars. And
you probably also know that turbos come
with some amount of lag. So, you'll put
your foot down and then that boost
pressure will have to build up until the
turbo is ready to go and is giving you
the most boost. Now, putting an electric
motor right in the front and keeping it
spun up constantly will actually be able
to keep the air flowing quickly and keep
it always on boost all the time. So,
what they did with this car is instead
of having twin turbos like the Turbo S,
for example, where you can hopefully
have a smaller turbo that builds boost
pressure faster, this is one huge turbo,
but because the electric motors keeping
it spun up all the time, it's basically
always ready to be right on boost. And
as you drive, there's essentially no
turbo lag. It's kind of amazing knowing
how big the single turbo is in this car
and driving this around and feeling like
you're always getting a responsive pedal
all the time like a naturally aspirated
engine is great. It's awesome. You
wouldn't necessarily know that that's
because of the turbo or because of the
electric motor, but it is and it's
hugely awesome. So, I I definitely
appreciate that. Now, here's the other
uh small benefit. You know, this is the
992.2, too. So, this is the fully
digital tachometer up here. And there's
also sadly uh a generic start engine
button instead of, you know, the
remember the turnkey start the the
heritage. Remember that? Anyway, you
press this and and and take a listen to
how it sounds when you press this.
[Music]
I don't know if you caught that. It's
kind of hard to catch on this mic, but
there was no ignition sound. the engine
just spun up and just started right away
because of that other electric motor. No
crank to start. The electric motor just
starts the engine. And uh this totally
reworked engine actually sounds a little
bit different. I I'm going to try to get
a good clip of uh the engine note so you
can hear it.
It's kind of nice. I think it kind of
sounds similar to the V8 from the
Cayenne GTS, actually. Uh, so it's
always got this low rumble. And as you
drive this car, because of the turbos,
because you're always essentially given
almost instant boost, you mostly drive
around under 2500, 2,000 RPM, and it's
happy to sit under 2,000 RPM. Those
other twin turbo cars, you know, you sit
around in normal mode and they feel
almost kind of bogged down. If you read
or watch any other reviews, people
instantly flip to sport mode so they can
drive around at higher RPM. This car is
happy to sit at lower RPM and still feel
responsive, which is awesome. So, the
conclusion that I've come to after
driving and living with this car for a
couple days now is um I get why Porsche
did it. It is that engineering
masterpiece that the 911 always is. This
is the most responsive single turbo
setup ever in a production car. And it's
so good of a hybrid that you can drive
it and not really ever know it's a
hybrid. Of course, there is also the
emissions reasons why they've done this.
Of course, you'll also probably get
slightly better gas mileage from driving
around at lower RPMs, but as you drive
the 911, the GTS, the character of the
GTS is still very much alive. It is
still confidence inspiring and planted.
Rear wheel steer is standard. It is
still incredibly wellb built. It is
still super practical. All the space in
the back. The front trunk is the same
size. The packaging is great. I love
black wheels. I don't even think you
need the carbon ceramics. I think these
brakes, which are still drilled, are
fantastic. It's just a slightly new
insides, which I would argue have
basically no downside. The slightly
heavier weight is basically
undetectable. And uh I think it leaves
the only downside of this car really
being that it is so freaking expensive.
the prices keep going up for 911s and
people keep buying them because they're
still great cars. But other than that, I
think they've done uh surprise an
incredible job. I uh I still prefer
the older uh 992.1.
Some things about it, and this is this
is me feeling like I'm becoming that old
person who I always thought it was weird
that they prefer the older Porsches, but
now I'm immediately that guy. I like the
turnkey ignition start as small as that
is. I like the analog tachometer as
small as that was. Uh but if you're if
you're in the market for a new 911,
yeah, this thing's great obviously.
Thanks for watching. Catch you in the
next one. Peace.

title: Hybrids aren't always the answer?
description:
The V8-version of the Lexus LC500 is better than the Hybrid in more ways than one.

Shot on iPhone 16 Pro Max
Rode Wireless Micro: https://geni.us/FBnQh
transcript:
All right. I bet normally on this
channel you'd expect me to take the
hybrid version over the gas powered
version of a car every single time, but
this LC500 right here from Lexus, well,
this is a funny one. See, we have
reviewed the Lexus LC500 hybrid on this
channel, and we weren't really that
impressed. But this this is just a
straight gas version of the same car. It
has a naturally aspirated V8, and it
sounds really good.
Now, a hybrid version of a car is
usually a little bit heavier, but also
adds a little bit of quickness thanks to
the electrical assist. But what's funny
is the V8 version of this car is 100 lb
lighter and is still quicker. 0 to 60.
Now, obviously lighter weight, better
sound. This V8 version is going to be
more playful and fun to drive, but did
you know it also goes further on a full
tank than the hybrid? But then the final
nail in the coffin, this V8 version is
also cheaper than the hybrid. So, uh, I
guess if you're Lexus, then hybrid isn't
always the answer.

title: Reviewing my First Car: Toyota Camry Hybrid!
description:
My first car has come a lonnnggg way.

transcript:
So, my first car ever was uh junior year
of college. Um I remember this cuz all
the upper classmen had cars. All the
younger kids didn't. And the way it
worked was I played ultimate frisbee.
And if you're on the team, every time we
go to a tournament, we'd all pack up in
one of the upper classman's cars and go
for a road trip. And when all the
seniors graduated, we lost all their
cars. And so, we needed some people to
get new cars. So, when I got up to being
a junior, I needed to get a car that was

used red Toyota Camry XLE. This is a
2014. These are the actual pictures I
took of that thing the day I bought it.

red Camry from around this year, I think
of mine. And I averaged 37 12 mp gallon
lifetime with that thing. It was sick.
And I remember that because I played the
little efficiency graphic in the screen
in the front of the car like a video
game. Like I wanted to max my high
score. Like if I got downhill enough for
a long enough drive, I could get into
the 40s. 40 m per gallon. It was crazy
back then. That was my idea of fun as a
college student. Anyway, this this is
the newest Toyota Camry. And so I

I'll talk about some of the extra trim

naturally aspirated inline 4 cylinder.
And uh there's actually three electric
motors. There's two at the front and one

And when you combine that gas and
electric, it's 232 combined horsepower.
That's not actually that little. That's
surprisingly peppy. I'll talk about

550 mi. The Camry's main goal is

what's funny is you can definitely still

or something like that. So, don't do

lower, economical option still. Now, I'm
going to be totally honest. I think the
new Camry looks really good. Similar to
how this bird up here looks way better
than your average Seagull. This car
looks way better than your average older
Camry. It's got this nice grill up front
here. Kind of blocks out some of the
sides, but then has a little second
arrow feature. I like that. That's a
reflector. There's your headlights.
Similar to the Prius's look. I think
it's nice. You come along to the side
here. It's obviously the gray color and
you kind of see the red seats. So,
that's kind of cheating, but nice wheel
design. You flow down the sides, you've
got some nice shapes and then the black

lower look if you ask me. And then XSSE

actually put a real spoiler on it
because you still need this car to slip

But, you know, black contrast that kind
of looks nice. And then look down here.
Look, dual tail pipes. Not bad. Lots of
nice lines on this car. Dare I say even
sporty a little bit. Look, look at that
diffuser down at the bottom. And this
black trim. It's not the point,
obviously. But here, let's get into the
practicality features cuz if you hold
down that trunk, it will automatically
open up all the way. And yes, it's a
Camry. So, it's got a nice fullsize
trunk
and nice spare. So, you're never going
to be out in the cold without that.
Obviously, the trunk is important for a
Camry. And this would absolutely still
qualify if I was trying to get a car
like this today because look at this
interior. This is going to remind you a
little bit of the Prius, but a lot of
Toyota cars all look pretty similar in
this way. Now, this is a bright red
leather interior, and I kind of I I like

of EVs nowadays, when you let off the

are on. So, in case you were wondering
if the brake lights were actually on,
you'll always be able to tell. Now, one
more thing that's way better about this
new Camry than the old one, uh, the
cameras are way better, which shouldn't
be a surprise for 2025, but they are.
Now, if I hit that camera view button,
it starts doing this like weird 360
animation thing. I'm not sure why it
plays that every time, but if I just put
the car in reverse, hits up that rear
camera and an overhead top down 360
view. You can see everything here. You
can correct for distortion or show the
ultrawide version. You can show
different lane markings or turn them off
completely. This is great. I'm I am
definitely guilty of being one of those
people that can only park um with
cameras. So, I was very happy to have
the cameras back then and they're even
better now. Okay, let's check out the
back seat because if you are going to be
transporting people, you want to at
least have a decent enough legroom.
Maybe if you're transporting ultimate
frisbee athletes or college kids that
are somewhat tall, you'd care about
this. So, for the back here for a road
trip, honestly, very acceptable. I've
been in the backseat of my own car many
times, and this feels very similar. The
fact that everything is bright red, I'm
also definitely liking that. Um, but you
also have this this glass up here, which
this uh I believe, yeah, you can motor
this open or closed, which is nice. Some
nice storage here, your vents here, no
screens needed, and some power with
USBA or USBC. The shape of the Camry
means the the sloping roof line kind of
cuts in a little bit. And they have
these cutouts over each seat to give you
a little bit more headroom, but if
you're tall like me, you could find, or
at least if you have a lot of hair like
me, you could find that you are up
against the ceiling. Honestly, not a
horrible amount of headroom, but
something to keep in mind. I think I
would have still been very tempted by
this car if this exact type of spec
existed back in 2014. Now, driving the
car itself, obviously, you're not buying
this as a performance car. It's not a
sports car, but I will note that a
highlight of it is one, it rides very
well. It's very comfortable. The
suspension is tuned to just be a
cruiser, and it's a lot peppier than I
remember, which must mean it is is
quicker. 232 horsepower is not going to
blow anyone's mind, but because of the
electric drivetrain and the hybrid
system, Toyota's got this tuned where if
you move that pedal down a little bit,
you can sort of zip up and into spots
and out of spots very, very easily. It's
got some pep to its step, which is
exciting. I did not expect that of this
car, but it pulls that off really well.
So, it's comfortable, suspension rides
well, and it's got some pep. So, look, I
I get why Toyota continues to do the
hybrid thing because number one, they've
gotten really really good at it. Number
two, they've also kind of committed to
it. Like, they do make that one EV that
I reviewed that's not very good. Um, but
they've kind of got this whole range of
cars now at a bunch of different price
points where they can offer you
something that's going to make sense and
economical and get you a ton of miles
per gallon, and that's what everybody
wants. So, I'm a fan of this new Camry.
I I love that there's new sensors
everywhere and there's new, you know,

that, too. And uh I think it looks
pretty good. Maybe I'm biased because
I've liked Camry in the past, but well
done Toyota. Keep making good cars like

Catch you in the next one. Peace.

livable M car I like to say that all of
the new M cars can be used as daily
driver sedans but this is truly one that
you could comfortably Drive every day
and won't beat you up so if there's
anything that's been improved with this
new M5 objectively that's the Comfort
levels because it is a really
comfortable car to drive can you
certainly feel the weight when taking
this car into corners and bends
absolutely without any question it feels
like a heavy car but for someone who's
into cars but not a hardcore Enthusiast
who grew up driving lotuses and Miatas
and Cayman and things like that I don't
think it's something that a lot of
people are going to care about which is
why I honestly think they'll probably do
well selling these new m5s just because
it delivers all the same things that the
M5 fundamentally is opposed to do high
speed high performance it is capable in
the corners despite you feeling the
weight it never is overcome by the
weight and any situation I put it in
dynamically it's been able to handle but
you can obviously feel that mass and
from a practicality standpoint it's a
more usable M5 than what you had before
because you have now 25 M of EV only
range and it's obviously going to be
noticeably more fuel efficient overall
because you have this hybrid setup than
the last gen M5 and you still get the V8
you get all the cool V8 sounds that you
want it's not super loud and Rowdy as
the other generation of the M5 were but
you can still hear it and still
appreciate that V8 sound so really this
car is still doing everything that the
M5 is supposed to do fundamentally
highspeed autobond capable cruising in
Comfort with luxury features the heated
ventilated seats you have great Bowers
and Wilkins speakers in here it's doing
all that stuff pretty well and so when
you get over all the 5400 lb humbug it's
still a pretty great daily driver in
very capable from a performance
standpoint for the street no one who's
going to buy an M5 even the last gen M5
it was likely going to take it to a
track anyway it was to have a nice cool
luxury sedan that was fast on the RO and
that's exactly what this new M5 does
despite it being bigger and heavier and
so overall this car gets my
recommendation as a performance car
would I personally buy one probably not
but I feel like for someone who just
wants a nice luxury performance car the
M5 still does everything that you want
it to do and so for that reason it gets
a recommendation for me but let me know
what you guys think about this new M5 in
the comments Down Below have they ruined
it is the weight too much is it being a
hybrid something that makes you not
consider it at all should they have just
made the new M5 completely electric
instead let me know your thoughts in the

channel for future content like this
thanks for watching and I'll talk to you
guys in the next one
